docs.snippet: Twickenham Film Studios, the venerable British studio founded in 1913 and used for the Beatles's ''Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!,'' among other classic films, is set to close by June because of financial troubles.     Gerald Krasner, the administ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Twickenham Film Studios, the venerable British studio founded in 1913 and used for the Beatles's ''Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!,'' among other classic films, is set to close by June because of financial troubles. Gerald Krasner, the administrator handling the closing, told The Telegraph that the studio had lost money over the past three years and that all 17 employees would be laid off within the next six months. ''It will not be retained as a film studio, because there is no way of making it pay as a film studio,'' Mr. Krasner said.
docs.abstract: Twickenham Film Studios, the venerable British studio founded in 1913, is set to close due to financial troubles. Photo (M)2

docs.lead_paragraph: As new “parent-trigger” laws seem poised to allow parents to take over failing schools, they’re already the stuff of Hollywood drama.
docs.abstract: Daniel Barnz film Won't Back Down, which tells a fictional story of a fiercely contested school takeover, addresses the controversies surrounding the real-life 'parent-trigger' state laws that allow parents to dump bad teachers and overrule administrators in bottom-ranked schools.

headline.seo: Viola Davis and Maggie Gyllenhaal in ‘Parent-Trigger’ Film

docs.abstract: David Plouffe, senior adviser to Pres Obama, has asserted himself as the main orchestrator of his political strategy, with a first-among-equals status in White House’s closed circle; Plouffe, who once sold knives door to door, managed Obama's campaign in 2008 and rejoined his team in 2011 after a lucrative hiatus.
